paper.title: Bikelution: Federated Gradient-Boosting for Scalable Shared Micro-Mobility Demand Forecasting
paper.abstract: The rapid growth of dockless bike-sharing systems has generated massive spatio-temporal datasets useful for fleet allocation, congestion reduction, and sustainable mobility. Bike demand, however, depends on several external factors, making traditional time-series models insufficient. Centralized Machine Learning (CML) yields high-accuracy forecasts but raises privacy and bandwidth issues when data are distributed across edge devices. To overcome these limitations, we propose Bikelution, an effic

memory_insight.before_after_comparisons: Bikelution reduces memory usage by 30% compared to its CML-based variant

analysis.engineering_takeaway: Implementing gradient quantization and Huffman coding can significantly reduce memory usage in Federated Learning models
technical_details: Intel Xeon E5-2699 v4 CPU (64 GB)
analysis.deployment_feasibility: Yes, Bikelution can be deployed on both mobile and laptop devices, but may require optimization for smaller RAM sizes

review_questions: Is this genuinely a breakthrough? Or incremental improvement?
